bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, March 25, 1724

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker, March 25, 1724, to inform him of the arrival of one of his ships which is in the York River. He hopes to send some leaf tobacco in the ship and notifies him of bills of exchange.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, March 25, 1724

opener.dateline:
per the Bailey [Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Mar. 25. 1724—
Mr. Edward Tucker

div1.p:
This is a Short line Via Londo. to advise You
that I have heard of Yor.small Vessel being in York delivering Goods
to Your friends there & is reported to be coming our way after,
but see nothing of her Yet am in hopes I may have something in
her, if I send You any Tobo. this Year it must be leaf for my Stemd
is all gon, Mr. Lawrence I must own made me an Offer of freit
but I had so far Engaged myself by promisses to the Londoners that I
was afraid to let him have any, I have wishd since I had, I
herein send You some Bills of Exche. drawn upon Yor. Self
=to Witt Jno. Hudnals for £19"11s & John Sharpleigh for £10"9"4
to be placd to my Accot. or Else to return protested, the rest is to
Wish Yor. health & to Subscribe

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1723 July 4 -1724 June 11, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The address has been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.
